title: 107_s2816
content:
The "Foreign and Armed Services Tax Fairness Act of 2002" is the short title of the Act. Any amendments or repeals in the Act refer to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Sec. 1. Short title; etc.
Sec. 2. Restoration of full exclusion from gross income of death gratuity payment.
Sec. 3. Special rule for members of uniformed services and Foreign Service in determining exclusion of gain from sale of principal residence.
Sec. 4. Qualified military base realignment and closure fringe benefit.
Sec. 5. Extension of tax filing delay provisions to military personnel serving in contingency operations.
Sec. 6. Deduction of certain expenses of members of the reserve component.
Sec. 7. Modification of membership requirement for exemption from tax for veterans' organizations.
Sec. 8. Clarification of the treatment of dependent care assistance programs sponsored by the Department of Defense for members of the Armed Forces. Defense for members of the Armed Forces of the United States. SEC. 2. RESTORATION OF FULL EXCLUSION FROM GROSS INCOME OF DEATH GRATUITY PAYMENT. Amends subsection (b)(3) of section 134 to exclude adjustments to death gratuity payments under chapter 75 of title 10, United States Code, made by law enacted after September 9, 1986. Effective for deaths occurring after September 10, 2001. SEC. 3. SPECIAL RULE FOR MEMBERS OF UNIFORMED SERVICES AND FOREIGN SERVICE IN DETERMINING EXCLUSION OF GAIN FROM SALE OF PRINCIPAL RESIDENCE. Members of uniformed services and foreign service can suspend the 5-year period for exclusion of gain from the sale of a principal residence during qualified official extended duty. The maximum extension allowed is 5 years. Members of uniformed services and foreign service can extend the 5-year period for excluding gain from selling a principal residence by serving at a duty station at least 50 miles away or residing in Government quarters under orders. The term "uniformed services" is defined as per section 101(a)(5) of title 10, United States Code. The term 'member of the Foreign Service' is defined in the Foreign Service Act of 1980. 'Extended duty' refers to duty exceeding 90 days or for an indefinite period. An election under subparagraph (A) can only be made for one property at a time. The amendment allows for the revocation of an election made under subparagraph (A) at any time. This amendment applies to elections made after the enactment of the Act for suspended periods under the Internal Revenue Code beginning after that date. SEC. 4. QUALIFIED MILITARY BASE REALIGNMENT AND CLOSURE FRINGE BENEFIT. Section 132 is amended to include a new qualified military base realignment and closure fringe benefit, defined as payments to offset adverse effects on housing. The amendments made by this section shall apply to payments made after the date of the enactment of this Act. SEC. 5. Extension of tax filing delay provisions to military personnel serving in contingency operations. Section 7508(a) is amended to include individuals deployed outside the US for contingency operations designated by the Secretary of Defense. Amendments include extending time for performing certain acts during the period of such contingency operation. Conforming amendments are also made. The amendments made by this section extend time for performing acts during contingency operations. Effective date applies to acts not expired before enactment of the Act. SEC. 6. DEDUCTION OF CERTAIN EXPENSES OF MEMBERS OF THE RESERVE COMPONENT. SEC. 6 amends Section 162 to allow deductions for expenses of members of the reserve component of the Armed Forces, regardless of itemization. Section 162 is amended to allow deductions for expenses of reserve component members of the Armed Forces, effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 2001. SEC. 7. Modification of membership requirement for exemption from tax for veterans' organizations. Amends section 501(c)(19) to include ancestors or lineal descendants. Effective for taxable years after enactment. SEC. 8. Clarification of dependent care assistance programs for members of the Armed Forces. Section 134(b) is amended to include dependent care assistance programs for members of the Armed Forces. Conforming amendments are made to sections 3121(a)(18), 3306(b)(13), and 3401(a)(18). The effective date for these amendments is for taxable years starting after December 31, 2001. No inferences can be drawn from these changes. No inference can be drawn from the amendments made to section 134(b)(4) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 regarding the tax treatment of amounts for taxable years before January 1, 2002.
